body:
Starting with `play-scala-seed` I wasn't able to reproduce:

Routes:
```
GET     /                           controllers.HomeController.index
GET     /redirected                           controllers.HomeController.redirected
```

HomeController:
```scala
  def index() = Action { implicit request: Request[AnyContent] =>
    Redirect("/redirected").flashing("success" -> "Computer has been created")
  }

  def redirected() = Action { implicit request: Request[AnyContent] =>
    Ok(request.flash.toString)
  }
```

Network headers seen in Chrome 59 on Mac OS 10.12.5:

Response to `http://localhost:9000/`:

```
HTTP/1.1 303 See Other
Location: /redirected
Set-Cookie: PLAY_FLASH=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9.eyJkYXRhIjp7InN1Y2Nlc3MiOiJDb21wdXRlciBoYXMgYmVlbiBjcmVhdGVkIn0sIm5iZiI6MTQ5OTAyNTM3OSwiaWF0IjoxNDk5MDI1Mzc5fQ.rFPs1p6w432kVSabiSpLaQz4obzM0pKWwiw_oqPs1PQ; SameSite=Lax; Path=/; HTTPOnly
Referrer-Policy: origin-when-cross-origin, strict-origin-when-cross-origin
X-Frame-Options: DENY
X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block
X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'
X-Permitted-Cross-Domain-Policies: master-only
Date: Sun, 02 Jul 2017 19:56:19 GMT
Content-Length: 0
```

Response to `http://localhost:9000/redirected`:
```
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Set-Cookie: PLAY_FLASH=; Max-Age=-86400; Expires=Sat, 01 Jul 2017 19:56:19 GMT; Path=/; HTTPOnly
Referrer-Policy: origin-when-cross-origin, strict-origin-when-cross-origin
X-Frame-Options: DENY
X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block
X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'
X-Permitted-Cross-Domain-Policies: master-only
Date: Sun, 02 Jul 2017 19:56:19 GMT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
Content-Length: 48

Flash(Map(success -> Computer has been created))
```

Can you please confirm with your browser version info and show the headers you get back for the redirect and the view?

I have tested everything again.

1. Your example works fine.

2. I've compared Anorm Example project for versions 2.5 and 2.6. In [header25.txt](https://github.com/playframework/playframework/files/1118154/header25.txt) and [header26.txt](https://github.com/playframework/playframework/files/1118152/header26.txt) you can see headers received after deleting a computer as was described earlier. In case of version 2.6 request.flash is empty and also the application generates SignatureException during runtime when flash is used (see [warning.txt](https://github.com/playframework/playframework/files/1118156/warning.txt)).

3. Another my project, which was created from seed but which uses Anorm, generates the same [exception](https://github.com/playframework/playframework/files/1118156/warning.txt)).

Thanks for that info. I have reproduced now on 2.6.0 using the Anorm example template you linked above. I get the same error in the console. It looks like Play's doesn't trust the Flash cookie value the browser provides in the `Cookie` header. It's possible that there's some config migration needed in the Anorm example template, but I'm not familiar with this area of Play so I'm not sure.

```
[warn] p.a.m.DefaultJWTCookieDataCodec - decode: could not decode JWT: JWT signature does not match locally computed signature. JWT validity cannot be asserted and should not be trusted.
io.jsonwebtoken.SignatureException: JWT signature does not match locally computed signature. JWT validity cannot be asserted and should not be trusted.
	at io.jsonwebtoken.impl.DefaultJwtParser.parse(DefaultJwtParser.java:354)
	at io.jsonwebtoken.impl.DefaultJwtParser.parse(DefaultJwtParser.java:481)
	at io.jsonwebtoken.impl.DefaultJwtParser.parseClaimsJws(DefaultJwtParser.java:541)
	at play.api.mvc.JWTCookieDataCodec$JWTFormatter.parse(Cookie.scala:652)
	at play.api.mvc.JWTCookieDataCodec.decode(Cookie.scala:577)
	at play.api.mvc.JWTCookieDataCodec.decode$(Cookie.scala:569)
	at play.api.mvc.DefaultJWTCookieDataCodec.decode(Cookie.scala:742)
	at play.api.mvc.FallbackCookieDataCodec.decode(Cookie.scala:728)
	at play.api.mvc.FallbackCookieDataCodec.decode$(Cookie.scala:719)
	at play.api.mvc.DefaultFlashCookieBaker.decode(Flash.scala:91)
```

The relevant headers are:

```
POST /computers/381/delete HTTP/1.1
Cookie: PLAY_SESSION=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9.eyJkYXRhIjp7ImNzcmZUb2tlbiI6IjM1MmEwMzgyY2FkMzc5MDM5MzcxMzlmYTRmYWJkNDE3NDQzMzg4NzAtMTQ5OTA2NjM0NTkxMC1lMDAwN2U5YTlkMjE2MjA4YmMzZTdlZmEifSwibmJmIjoxNDk5MDY2MzQ1LCJpYXQiOjE0OTkwNjYzNDV9.ZixAKHxhtg5BMSwZF5Lzy9wXU2aSQgkD-AX8h4TZSNY

HTTP/1.1 303 See Other
Location: /computers
Set-Cookie: PLAY_FLASH=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9.eyJkYXRhIjp7InN1Y2Nlc3MiOiJDb21wdXRlciBoYXMgYmVlbiBkZWxldGVkIn0sIm5iZiI6MTQ5OTA3MDAyMCwiaWF0IjoxNDk5MDcwMDIwfQ.PofrruigaE3IMZ9Zkyi0ZAynja4ctiB7hUBz2BicixY; SameSite=Lax; Path=/; HTTPOnly

GET /computers HTTP/1.1
Cookie: PLAY_SESSION=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9.eyJkYXRhIjp7ImNzcmZUb2tlbiI6IjM1MmEwMzgyY2FkMzc5MDM5MzcxMzlmYTRmYWJkNDE3NDQzMzg4NzAtMTQ5OTA2NjM0NTkxMC1lMDAwN2U5YTlkMjE2MjA4YmMzZTdlZmEifSwibmJmIjoxNDk5MDY2MzQ1LCJpYXQiOjE0OTkwNjYzNDV9.ZixAKHxhtg5BMSwZF5Lzy9wXU2aSQgkD-AX8h4TZSNY; PLAY_FLASH=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9.eyJkYXRhIjp7InN1Y2Nlc3MiOiJDb21wdXRlciBoYXMgYmVlbiBkZWxldGVkIn0sIm5iZiI6MTQ5OTA3MDAyMCwiaWF0IjoxNDk5MDcwMDIwfQ.PofrruigaE3IMZ9Zkyi0ZAynja4ctiB7hUBz2BicixY

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
...
```

It seems the issue is somehow related to database evolutions. In case of any evolution required `request.flash` will be empty. It means that when in-memory database is used flash will be always empty. When database is located in a disc storage, it is necessary to restart an application after applying an evolution to make flash working.
The issue doesn't depend on further database access.

How to test using  [Play Scala Anorm Example](https://example.lightbend.com/v1/download/play-scala-anorm-example):

1. Run project and apply database evolution.
2. Click on "ACE" computer name.
3. Click on "Delete this Computer". Message about computer deletion doesn't appear.

How make it working:

1. Reconfigurate database in application.conf. For example comment this row `db.default.url="jdbc:h2:mem:play"` and add `db.default.url="jdbc:h2:~/sample"`
2. Run project and apply database evolution.
3. Click on "ACE" computer name.
4. Click on "Delete this Computer". Message about computer deletion doesn't appear.
5. Restart the application.
6. Click on "Acer Extensa" computer name.
7. Click on "Delete this Computer". Message about computer deletion appears. So flash is correct now.

Steps 3-4 are optional just to make sure that flash is empty after applying evolution.

Another way to test is to use [Temp.zip](https://github.com/playframework/playframework/files/1118899/Temp.zip) project, which is created from Play Scala Anorm Example. Here dummy data are used and there is no reading from database. So the project can be tested without evolutions. Steps for testing are the same.

For p.a.m.DefaultJWTCookieDataCodec warning (which is in fact an error, since cookies are ignored), try "-Duser.timezone=Europe/London" (my native timezone is more to the east). Not sure why this happens, but I am facing this problem: sessions don't work at all. With timezone set to Europe/London, everything works.
It has nothing to do with anorm - it happens even in project that does not use migrations or anorm (code in https://github.com/playframework/playframework/issues/7533#issuecomment-312513723 does NOT work without timezone set to Europe/London).

This:

```
[warn] p.a.m.DefaultJWTCookieDataCodec - decode: could not decode JWT: JWT signature does not match locally computed signature. JWT validity cannot be asserted and should not be trusted.
io.jsonwebtoken.SignatureException: JWT signature does not match locally computed signature. JWT validity cannot be asserted and should not be trusted.
	at io.jsonwebtoken.impl.DefaultJwtParser.parse(DefaultJwtParser.java:354)
	at io.jsonwebtoken.impl.DefaultJwtParser.parse(DefaultJwtParser.java:481)
	at io.jsonwebtoken.impl.DefaultJwtParser.parseClaimsJws(DefaultJwtParser.java:541)
	at play.api.mvc.JWTCookieDataCodec$JWTFormatter.parse(Cookie.scala:652)
	at play.api.mvc.JWTCookieDataCodec.decode(Cookie.scala:577)
	at play.api.mvc.JWTCookieDataCodec.decode$(Cookie.scala:569)
	at play.api.mvc.DefaultJWTCookieDataCodec.decode(Cookie.scala:742)
	at play.api.mvc.FallbackCookieDataCodec.decode(Cookie.scala:728)
	at play.api.mvc.FallbackCookieDataCodec.decode$(Cookie.scala:719)
	at play.api.mvc.DefaultFlashCookieBaker.decode(Flash.scala:91)
```

Is related to #7530. If you try using a private/incognito tab where there are not previous cookies, then you shouldn't see this warning.

Sorry, it is not related to the issue above.

I was able to reproduce it too.

> code in #7533 (comment) does NOT work without timezone set to Europe/London

I'm pretty sure my timezone is `Pacific/Auckland` and it worked for me.

However, if changing the timezone changes the behaviour for you then that's a good clue. It could be related to `Cookie` expiration or JWT might have a lease time on its tokens.
I think we need to put a breakpoint into https://github.com/jwtk/jjwt/blob/master/src/main/java/io/jsonwebtoken/impl/DefaultJwtParser.java#L351 to see what is invalid about the signature.
I'm going to take a shot at debugging this now.

issue.title: Reload server HTTP configuration when app changes

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
Fixes #7533.

This fixes a bug that can occur in dev mode where the server and application can end up with different keys for signing and verifying cookies.

At the moment, if the application fails to start in dev mode, e.g. due to an evolutions failure or compile error, the server will load invalid default keys. The server's keys will persist even when the application is properly loaded again. This means that the server and application can end up with different keys. Since the server manages key signing, while the application manages key verification, it becomes possible in dev mode for the server to sign cookies that can't later be verified by the application.

This fix ensures that the key configuration is reloaded when the application starts again or changes, which means that the keys used for cookie signing and verification should match properly.

body:
@richdougherty There probably isn't separate bug, just failure on my side. When I was reproducing this error with your code (https://github.com/playframework/playframework/issues/7533#issuecomment-312513723), I created project from seed, ran it, modifying code while it was starting -- since it takes a while -- which caused failure (since in both cases I have changed routes first and they pointed to non existent action in controller) and broke the keys. Then it worked with timezone, because it was different clean start. Other projects were broken by evolutions. My own test mini project without evolutions was borked by unbealiaveble cascade that contained every possible wrong step multiplied by https://github.com/playframework/playframework/pull/7530 (since cookies were signed by invalid key). Your test code indeed works even without any timezone changes after I started it again with clean browser.
I apologize for my derailing analysis.
